audio_descriptions.notes:
Objective 

This an audio description project that will provide a series of descriptions for “The Sunken Place” scene in the film Get Out, directed by Jordan Peele. I will be providing descriptions from the objective, emotional, and sociological perspectives. The following description is from the objective perspective. 

We are about to enter a scene in which Mrs. Armitage, a white, affluent psychiatrist secretly hypnotizes Chris, an African American photographer who is also dating Mrs. Armitage’s white daughter. Mrs. Armitage is sitting on a flowered chair across from Chris, who is sitting on a red leather armchair. 

Chris stares back at Mrs. Armitage inquisitively and looks tortured as he thinks deeply. 

We enter Chris’s thoughts and see him as a child sitting criss-crossed in front of a TV. 

Mrs. Armitage stirs her tea with a teaspoon. 

Chris somberly stares ahead with dead eyes. 

Patronizing surprise 

Chris vigorously scratches at the chair arms. 

He cries with his eyes wide open, tears streaming down his face. 

Chris falls suddenly and then in slow motion into the blackness away from Mrs. Armitage, who is now projected onto a screen. 

He flails around in the darkness, seemingly an endless galaxy with stars. 

As Chris falls, he looks up at the shrinking image of Mrs. Armitage. 

He swims in the air, trying to claw his way back to reality but he continues to fall. 

He has fallen far below Mrs. Armitage and stares up at her shrinking figure. 

Sitting on the armchair, Chris cries wide-eyed, his mouth in an open gape. 

Mrs. Armitage leans forward to look at Chris.

Chris, hypnotized, blinks helplessly at Mrs. Armitage as her shrinking image peers down to look at him. 

Chris becomes desperate, flailing wildly, but unable to re-surface.

She places her hand on Chris's face and closes his eyelid. 

Blackness

He wakes up.

audio_descriptions.notes:
This an audio description project that will provide a series of descriptions for “The Sunken Place” scene in the film Get Out, directed by Jordan Peele. I will be providing descriptions from the objective, emotional, and sociological perspectives. The following description is from the emotional perspective. 

We are about to enter a scene in which Mrs. Armitage, a white, affluent psychiatrist secretly hypnotizes Chris, an African American photographer who is also dating Mrs. Armitage’s white daughter. Mrs. Armitage is sitting on a flowered chair across from Chris, who is sitting on a red leather armchair.

Watching Chris as a child sitting on the floor by himself in the dark, his basketball hoop in the corner, I feel so sorry for him and I can sense that he is trying his best to be distracted from his fear by watching TV. 

Mrs. Armitage’s gentle voice is belied by her condescending gaze and I feel extremely terrified of her. 

Nothing. The guilt that Chris still harbors is palpable and I am extremely angry at Mrs. Armitage for manipulating him to feel that way. 

This statement is extremely striking to me, how we can be stuck in a state of disillusionment because even as something is happening in real time, it doesn’t become real to us until we begin to bear its consequences. 

Watching Chris as a child scratch at his wooden chair, I feel so sympathetic for him. He said that he did nothing, but he is letting his worry tear him apart, and that's something.

As Chris falls into the sunken place, the music that plays in the background makes me feel trapped, like someone is directing or orchestrating my actions and I am not in control. 

The sound of the wind in the background reminds me how loud nothingness is, and I wonder if that’s how death feels. 

Chris crying with his eyes wide open is extremely jarring and I feel very disturbed. 

Seeing her hand touch his face, leaves me with goosebumps

The crescendo of noise at the end made me so afraid that something terrible was about to happen, and I felt relief seeing Chris waking up, until I realized that he is still in the Armitages' house.

audio_descriptions.notes:
This an audio description project that will provide a series of descriptions for “The Sunken Place” scene in the film Get Out, directed by Jordan Peele. I will be providing descriptions from the objective, emotional, and sociological perspectives. The following description is from the sociological perspective. 

We are about to enter a scene in which Mrs. Armitage, a white, affluent psychiatrist secretly hypnotizes Chris, an African American photographer who is also dating Mrs. Armitage’s white daughter. Mrs. Armitage is sitting on a flowered chair across from Chris, who is sitting on a red leather armchair.

Chris stares back at Mrs. Armitage inquisitively and looks tortured as he thinks deeply. 

We enter Chris’s thoughts and see him as a child sitting criss-crossed in front of a TV. 

Mrs. Armitage stirs her teacup with a silver teaspoon, hypnotizing Chris, but also mimicking slave masters, who summoned house slaves using tea cups. 

Chris somberly stares ahead with dead eyes. 

Patronizing surprise. 

Chris vigorously scratches at the armchair, which during a later scene is revealed to be stuffed with cotton, referencing the cotton that black slaves picked for hundreds of years. 

He cries with his eyes wide open, tears streaming down his face. 

Chris falls suddenly and then in slow motion into the blackness away from Mrs. Armitage, who is now projected onto a screen. 

He is immobilized and powerless in the grips of Mrs. Armitage’s trance. No matter how hard he screams, he is silenced, symbolizing Black repression in America, from slavery, to the Tuskegee experiments, to the death of Travyon Martin. 

Watching Mrs. Armitage on the screen and unable to surface back to reality, Chris parallels his younger self watching TV during his mom's death and doing nothing.

As he falls into nothingness, watching the outside world on a screen, the fourth wall is broken. Like Chris the audience in the movie theater is also sitting in the blackness, watching a scene play out with no agency to change it. 

Hypnotized, Chris blinks helplessly at Mrs. Armitage as she peers down to look at him. 

The sunken place is the system that silences blacks, the disabled, women and other oppressed groups. 

She places her hand on Chris's face and closes his eyelid, rendering him helpless to even see reality.

result.title: Get Out (2017) - The Sunken Place Scene (1/10) | Movieclips
result.description:
Get Out - The Sunken Place: Chris (Daniel Kaluuya) is hypnotized by his girlfriend's mother (Catherine Keener).
BUY THE MOVIE: https://www.fandangonow.com/details/movie/get-out-2017/MMV6E28ED7A7CD182832782BB48F3594B5E8?cmp=Movieclips_YT_Description

Watch the best Get Out scenes & clips:
https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLZbXA4lyCtqoxOILCWye9cuElChrNh2Y9

FILM DESCRIPTION:
Now that Chris (Daniel Kaluuya) and his girlfriend, Rose (Allison Williams), have reached the meet-the-parents milestone of dating, she invites him for a weekend getaway upstate with Missy and Dean. At first, Chris reads the family's overly accommodating behavior as nervous attempts to deal with their daughter's interracial relationship, but as the weekend progresses, a series of increasingly disturbing discoveries lead him to a truth that he never could have imagined.

Director: Jordan Peele
Producer: Jason Blum
Screewriter: Jordan Peele
